awd_titl_txt: Laser Fabrication of Subnanometer Catalysts from Metal Organic Nanocapsules
awd_abstract_narration:
This award investigates a novel method of making small nanometer-sized clusters from metal organic nanocapsules using laser decomposition. These clusters are assembled on highly conductive graphene supports to form heterogeneous catalysts. The project involves experimental investigations of the nucleation, growth and stabilization of these clusters supported by computational modeling. This project leads to progress in laser science, material science, thermal science, and supramolecular chemistry, all of which advances the field of nanomanufacturing. The availability high-efficiency catalysts are important in chemical processes, metal-air batteries, flexible electronics and fuel cells, which greatly enhances U.S. industrial competitiveness in global markets, increases U.S. economic growth, and strengthens national security. This grant engages underrepresented minority students in chemistry and engineering. It has plans to improve local STEM education through an outreach programs such as Women Engineer and Scientist Day at Mizzou to stimulate high school girls' interests in science and engineering.

The project seeks to establish a computational and experimental framework to investigate how the laser induces the decomposition of metal organic nanocapsules and promotes nucleation of reactant intermediates to form sub-nanometer clusters on graphene support. Studies are conducted on the effects of the size of metal organic nanocapsules, which ranges from 1-2 nanometers, on the microstructures of the fabricated nanoclusters, and the effects of the support on their growth kinetics. Inherited from the study is the development of a serial of technique, bottom up supramolecular synthesis, in-situ catalyst conversion by laser-induced pyrolysis, molecular dynamics simulations of the fabrication mechanism, statistical analysis on the morphology of the fabricated nanoclusters, and analytical tools for characterizing and confirming the catalytic active sites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Supported heterogeneous electrocatalysts, especially those based on earth-abundant metals such iron (Fe), nickel (Ni), copper (Cu), and cobalt (Co), are critical to fuel cell, green hydrogen production, and chemical processing industry, thus contributing to sustainability of the society. This project aimed to develop a novel methodology based on direct laser induction to produce the electrocatalysts with precisely controlled structures for realizing high catalytic efficiency. This award funded research activities of synthesizing various types of metal organic nanocapsules (MONCs) and others as precursors, laser-processing functional nanomaterials from these precursors, investigating fundamental mechanisms associated with these processes via integrated experimentation and computation, and exploring the applications of the laser-processed nanomaterials for applications in high-efficiency electrocatalysis. The developed physics- and chemistry-informed data driven models enabled to disclose the fundamental understanding of transformation pathways of the various precursors to functional materials under the laser induced processing conditions. The obtained fundamental knowledge helped to establish rules for modulating the chemistry/structures of the precursors as well as the lasing processing variables to tailor the properties of the synthesized nanomaterials with high electrochemical performance. Moreover, based on the obtained new knowledge a scalable laser processing methodology was developed with advanced data-driven optimization algorithms, showing a translation potential for commercialization. In addition, this award also supported education and outreach activities for training graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students crossing the disciplines in physics, materials science, electrochemistry, manufacturing, reaction engineering, machine learning, and control. The research outcomes were disseminated to the public through peer-reviewed paper publication, conference presentations, and media report. The research results were also integrated with an existing course in manufacturing for broadening the impact in training the next-generational workface. In summary, the outcomes from the research, education, and outreach activities promoted new materials and new manufacturing process development, technology development and translation, and workforce development, thus in turn benefiting the society.

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2024
Modified by: Jian Lin
